Quantum theory is a branch of mathematics, and like all branches of mathematics, it has its own foundations. The foundations of quantum theory have been the subject of intense debate for the past century. In this paper, we provide a purely categorical approach to the foundations of quantum theory. Our approach is based on the observation that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators is equivalent to the category of continuous linear operators between the categories of probability spaces and Borel measures. This result provides a mathematical foundation for quantum theory that is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. Our approach is based on the work of von Neumann, Mackey, Jauch, Piron, Abramsky, and Coecke.

The origin of parasitism is one of the most important questions in biology. Here, we show that the Myxozoa, a group of microscopic parasites, are cnidarians, a group that includes corals, sea anemones, jellyfish, and hydroids. We also show that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic one was accompanied by extreme reduction in genome size and gene content. This study provides a unique perspective on the evolution of parasitism.

The virus has a complex life cycle and is able to evade the host immune response. In this study, we show that the virus is able to block the nuclear import of STAT1 and STAT2, which are key components of the IFN pathway. We found that the virus is able to hijack the Nup98-Rae1 complex to block nuclear import of the transcription factors. Our data provide a mechanism of viral antagonism that could be used as a starting point for the development of new antiviral strategies. (Read more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of these channels. In this study, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1 channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits Hv1 will further our understanding of Hv1 function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for Hv1 channels. Climate change is expected to increase the variability of crop yields, which will increase the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year. This instability in global grain trade and international grain prices will affect especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. We show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year is virtually zero today, but it increases to 7% under 2 °C warming and 86% under 4 °C warming. This increase in instability is due to a combination of a decrease in mean yields and an increase in the coefficient of variation of yields. Our results highlight the need for investments in breeding for heat tolerance.

The coexistence of species in a world of limited resources is one of the most enduring questions in ecology. In the case of large mammalian herbivores, the coexistence of species that differ in diet, body size, and digestive physiology is a puzzle. We show that DNA metabarcoding can be used to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap at a species level, and that this approach can be used to reveal that species that appear to be competitors are actually specialized in different ways. Our results suggest that the coexistence of species in savanna ecosystems may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized.

We conducted a survey of more than 5,800 small businesses in the United States to understand the impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations. We find that many small businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Moreover, the length of the crisis is negatively associated with the risk of closure. Finally, many small businesses are financially fragile, with only about 2 wk of cash on hand at the time of the survey.

Plastic debris is one of the most visible consequences of human activities in the ocean. However, the magnitude of the problem is still unclear. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is far less than expected, and that the main sink for the millimeter-sized fragments is a fast process of nano-fragmentation. This sink may involve a combination of processes yet to be discovered, such as the transference of the fragments to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and the removal of the fragments from the surface by fast processes. This study provides a better understanding of the fate of the missing plastic debris, and may help to clarify the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astronomy. The solar system is a unique laboratory for the study of the formation of other planetary systems. The solar system is also a unique laboratory for the study of the formation of other planetary systems.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the number of motorized vessels has increased exponentially. This has led to a significant increase in fishing effort, which has been accompanied by a decline in the effective catch per unit of effort. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries, challenging sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the energy available to the mother is one of the most important factors in determining the reproductive output of a species. Here, we show that the practice of allonursing, in which a mother nurses a dead or injured offspring, is the most important factor in increasing reproductive output.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder that affects the autonomic nervous system and the basal ganglia. The disease is characterized by the presence of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected neurons. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to reduce the load of α-syn aggregates in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of the monomeric and oligomeric forms of α-syn. Furthermore, VX-765 was able to limit the neurotoxic effects of α-syn aggregation by preserving tyrosine hydroxylase-positive neurons in the substantia nigra. These results suggest that VX-765 is a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in synucleinopathies by limiting α-syn accumulation. This would be a major step forward in the treatment of MSA and other synucleinopathies. (Read more)

The endothelium is the lining of the blood vessels and is the most numerous cell type in the human body. It is responsible for controlling the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between blood and tissue, controlling blood pressure, and controlling the clotting of blood. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. This paper describes the structure of the endothelial network, which is the communication system between the cells. The network is found to be a small-world network, which is a network configuration that is both efficient at local and global communication. This structure is found to be effective for the control of the functions of the endothelium. This work provides a new perspective on the structure of the endothelium and its role in the control of cardiovascular function.

The COVID-19 pandemic has generated enormous amounts of data, which are needed by many different audiences. We have created a data API that provides access to a wide range of COVID-19 data, including traditional public health surveillance signals and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. The data are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. This paper describes the data sources and signals, and provides examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion channels in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes, such as the control of heart rate and blood pressure, the transmission of nerve impulses, and the regulation of muscle contraction. Inactivation is a fundamental property of potassium channels that is essential for their function. Inactivation is also a major target for drug development. Here, we provide a structural explanation for the allosteric coupling between the activation and inactivation properties of potassium channels. We also provide a structural explanation for the lack of C-type inactivation in a family of potassium channels. Finally, we provide a structural explanation for the structural collapse of the channel’s selectivity filter, which is a key step in the process of closing the channel.

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem that is influenced by the host and the environment. In this study, we investigate the potential of anaerobic gut fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We found that anaerobic gut fungi synthesize a diverse array of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and other bioactive compounds. These results support the idea that anaerobic gut fungi are a source of natural products that could be used to regulate the composition of the gut microbiome. This work provides a foundation for the development of natural products from anaerobic gut fungi as a source of therapeutics and other bioactive compounds.

Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior, yet the mechanisms underlying the establishment of a social hierarchy remain largely unknown. Here we show that anxiety, a personality trait that predisposes an individual to become subordinate in a social encounter, is associated with reduced mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. We further demonstrate that the low social competitiveness associated with high anxiety is mediated by the nucleus accumbens and is dependent on mitochondrial function. Our findings highlight a key role for brain energy metabolism in social behavior and point to mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens as a potential marker and avenue of treatment for anxiety-related social disorders. Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of erythrocytes. The hemoglobin expression pattern in human erythrocytes is developmentally regulated, with fetal hemoglobin (HbF) being expressed in the fetus and newborn, and adult hemoglobin (HbA) being expressed in adults. Here we show that the mRNA-binding protein IGF2BP1 is expressed in the erythroid lineage and is able to reverse the adult hemoglobin expression pattern toward a more fetal-like phenotype. This is achieved by increased expression of the fetal gamma-globin and decreased expression of the adult beta-globin. This mechanism may be important for the development of fetal hemoglobin in humans.

Cancer is a leading cause of death worldwide, and the development of new therapies is urgently needed. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis, a form of regulated necrosis driven by iron-dependent peroxidation of phospholipids, in cancer cells. This resistance is mediated by mutation of phosphatidylinositol 3-kinase (PI3K) or loss of phosphatase and tensin homolog deleted on chromosome 10 (PTEN), two highly frequent events in cancer, and by activation of the PI3K-AKT-mTOR signaling axis. This resistance is overcome by inhibition of the mTORC1 signaling pathway, which is highly active in cancer, and by ferroptosis induction, which is a promising new strategy for cancer therapy. These findings provide a rationale for combination therapy with mTORC1 inhibition and ferroptosis induction in cancer. (Read more)

Hypertension is the leading cause of heart failure. The treatment of hypertension is a major challenge for the medical community. The most common drugs used to treat hypertension are calcium channel blockers. These drugs are effective, but their use is limited by the development of side effects. We have identified a mechanism by which calcium channel blockers promote vascular remodeling. Our findings may lead to the development of new drugs with fewer side effects.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP was effective in halting the decline of older-forest–associated birds, but not early-seral–associated birds. Our findings highlight the importance of maintaining older forests and the need to ensure that the creation of early-seral ecosystems does not impede the conservation and development of older-forest structure.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. This problem can be addressed by the development of new antibacterial agents to keep pace with the evolutionary adaptation of pathogens. Here, we present a rational design approach, in which acylide antibiotics were screened based on computational predictions of solubility, membrane permeability, and binding affinity toward the ribosome. To assess our design strategy, we tested all candidates for in vitro inhibitory activity and then evaluated them in vivo with several antibiotic-resistant strains to determine minimal inhibitory concentrations. The best compounds designed by us show activity, especially when combined with the membrane-weakening drug colistin, against Acinetobacter baumanii, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and Escherichia coli, which are the three most critical targets from the priority list of pathogens of the World Health Organization. This work provides a proof of concept for the use of computational predictions in the early stages of drug development. We introduce a simple and effective network architecture for image segmentation. The architecture is based on a single set of operations and is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The architecture is easy to implement, train, and apply in practice. We show that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters than popular existing architectures, with a reduced risk of overfitting the training data. The proposed architecture is expected to be useful in many image-processing problems.

The climate of the tropics is a critical component of the global energy budget, and the transport of moisture is a key process in the global water cycle. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. The shift in hydroclimate is consistent with a change in climate forcing at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition, and the lake-level variability is consistent with a climate drier than today. The climate variability exerted a profound influence on the Lake Malawi endemic cichlid fish species flock; the geographically extensive habitat reconfiguration provided novel ecological opportunities, enabling new populations to differentiate rapidly to distinct species. Our results provide a unique insight into the influence of climate variability on the evolution of species distributions and the associated ecological processes. The use of electronic devices in the hours before bedtime has become increasingly common, and the effects of this exposure on sleep and health are not well understood. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device for 1 h before bedtime reduces melatonin levels and the timing of the circadian clock, and reduces the next-morning alertness. These results have important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) chronostratigraphic boundary is widely recognized as marking a cooling of ∼5 °C in global temperature. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB is consistent with Os from terrestrial sources, and that the Os in the magnetic grains and microspherules is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the magnetic grains and microspherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

This study provides a comprehensive view of the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity. It shows that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity, but that its function is not limited to the control of self-reactive T cells, but also extends to the control of autoreactive B cells and Treg cells.

Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of this diversity remains poorly understood. We show that the evolution of beetles is linked to the evolution of plant cell wall-degrading enzymes, which may have enabled the evolution of specialized feeding habits, such as leaf mining and wood boring.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has led to the development of new variants of concern, which have shown resistance to the approved vaccines and antibodies. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that can be used to optimize the binding affinity of antibodies to the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2. We demonstrate the utility of our approach by optimizing the binding affinity of an antibody that is effective against the Alpha, Beta, and Gamma variants but not the Delta variant. Our optimized antibody can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our work highlights the power of deep learning in antibody engineering and its potential application to other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia and the fifth leading cause of death in the United States. The strongest genetic risk factor influencing susceptibility to AD is apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype. APOE has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. The presence of two copies of the E4 allele increases risk by ∼12-fold whereas E2 allele is associated with an ∼twofold decreased risk for AD. These data put APOE central to AD pathophysiology, but it is not yet clear how APOE alleles modify AD risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the phagocytic capacity of astrocytes that is highly dependent on APOE isoform.

The Earth's inner core is a solid core that is the densest part of the planet. It is believed to have formed by the crystallization of molten iron. However, the nucleation mechanism of the inner core is still a mystery. In this study, we show that the nucleation of the inner core is likely to be different from that of the outer core. This provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox, which has been a long-standing problem in geophysics.

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the effects of chronic marijuana use on the brain are well known, the effects of acute marijuana use on the brain are less clear. Here, we show that the brain’s response to the stimulation of dopamine (DA) is blunted in marijuana abusers, which might contribute to their negative emotionality and addictive behaviors. These findings have implications for the development of effective treatments for marijuana abuse.

Language is the most complex form of communication. It is also the most complex form of communication evolved to date. This paper shows that the latest advances in machine learning can be used to understand how the human brain processes language.

Deep learning has been a major breakthrough in machine learning, but it has been plagued by instability. We show that this instability is due to the fact that many deep learning algorithms are unstable in the sense of numerical analysis. We introduce a new class of algorithms that are stable, and we prove that this stability is a necessary condition for the existence of algorithms that can compute deep neural networks. This result has implications for the design of deep learning algorithms and for the theory of deep learning.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a major challenge for the world. It is also a major challenge for science. In the midst of a global crisis, scientists are increasingly relying on a classic psychological experiment to explain why people are not following the rules. The experiment is a classic example of a flawed experiment. It is discussed here as a cautionary tale against uncritically enshrining unsound research in the “lore” of a field of research.

Leprosy is a disease that has been with us for thousands of years. It is caused by two species of bacteria, Mycobacterium leprae and Mycobacterium lepromatosis, which are closely related and cause similar diseases. This study shows that the two species have retained many of the same genes, despite having diverged from their common ancestor approximately 14 million years ago. This suggests that the genes that are retained are important for the survival of the bacteria, and that the genes that are lost are not.

The entanglement dynamics is a key topic in the study of quantum quenches. It is also a fundamental problem in the study of isolated quantum systems, which are the most relevant ones in nature. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics in the space–time scaling limit can be understood in terms of quasiparticles, which are the elementary excitations of the system. This result is valid for both interacting and noninteracting systems, and it is exact in the case of integrable models. We check our result for the paradigmatic Heisenberg chain.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused more than 5 million deaths worldwide. The development of a vaccine is the only way to stop the pandemic. Here, we describe a vaccine candidate that is currently in clinical development. The vaccine candidate is based on a segment of the viral spike protein that has been recoded with synonymous suboptimal codon pairs, thereby introducing 283 silent mutations. In addition, the furin cleavage site within the spike protein was deleted from the viral genome for added safety of the vaccine strain. The vaccine candidate is temperature sensitive in vitro, yet grows robustly at the permissive temperature. In addition, the vaccine candidate is highly protective in a relevant hamster model. This, coupled with its large-scale manufacturing potential, supports its potential use in mass vaccination programs. Thus, the vaccine candidate described here may be a valuable addition to the arsenal against COVID-19. (Read more)

The Second Pandemic of plague, which occurred between the 14th and 19th centuries, led to high mortality and recurrent epidemics for hundreds of years. The vector of the disease is still debated, with the most common hypothesis being that rats were the main transmission pathway. Here, we show that human ectoparasites, such as fleas or lice, could have been the primary vector of the disease. This would have important implications for the control of the disease, as it would have been possible to target the vector rather than the reservoir, as was done for the control of the Black Death. Our results also suggest that the vector of the disease was not constant over time, which could have important implications for the understanding of the epidemiology of the disease.

The evolution of brain size is a key topic in the study of animal cognition. However, it is often difficult to disentangle the effects of brain size and the number of neurons on cognitive ability. This study shows that, in amniotes, the number of neurons is the main driver of cognitive ability, and the evolution of brain size is a consequence of the evolution of the number of neurons. This study also shows that the evolution of brain size is not the only way to increase the number of neurons in the brain.

Cancer is a disease of the cell cycle, and the development of new therapies is dependent on a better understanding of the molecular mechanisms that regulate the cell cycle. Here, we show that the mitochondrial molecular chaperone TRAP1 is a key regulator of the cell cycle.

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of the dynamics of actin filaments. It is known to sever filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not understood. Here, we show that ADF binds to filaments and that this binding enhances the rate at which filaments are severed. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results have implications for our understanding of the role of ADF in cell motility and for the design of new drugs that target ADF.

Fructose, a common sweetener in many foods and beverages, is known to be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. This study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater brain activation in regions involved in attention and reward processing, which may promote feeding behavior. In addition, the study shows that fructose ingestion results in greater hunger and desire for food and a greater willingness to give up long-term monetary rewards to obtain immediate high-calorie foods. These findings have implications for understanding the role of fructose in the development of obesity and its associated metabolic complications. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island, and we found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. We also found that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a sex-biased way, with a higher contribution of men from Southeast Asia and Africa. Finally, we found that the genetic structure of the population is influenced by geography, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in a heterogeneous way. These results provide a better understanding of the history of Madagascar and the origin of the Malagasy population. They also provide a better understanding of the human history of the Indian Ocean. We show that the amount of positive and negative content in a person’s Facebook News Feed influences that person’s own emotional state. This is the first experimental evidence for massive-scale emotional contagion via social networks. The results suggest that, in contrast to prevailing assumptions, in-person interaction and nonverbal cues are not strictly necessary for emotional contagion, and that the observation of others’ positive experiences constitutes a positive experience for people. This work also suggests that, in contrast to the assumption that people are only aware of their own emotions, people are aware of the emotions of others. This work has implications for the study of emotions, social psychology, and social networks.

Messenger RNA (mRNA) sequences can be modified after transcription, and these modifications can have important effects on protein synthesis. In this work, we show that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in mRNA codons can alter the rate of protein synthesis. We also show that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can increase the rate of near-cognate amino acid incorporation into a nascent peptide chain. These findings suggest that the presence of Ψ in mRNA can have a modest impact on translation, and that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in the course of decoding mRNA sequences. Our work provides a better understanding of the impact of mRNA modifications on translation, and may have implications for the development of mRNA-based therapeutics. (Read more)

This study shows that the feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health and social relationships. This finding has implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of body size in mammals is one of the most important and least understood aspects of mammalian evolution. This study shows that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. The existence of this body size attractor and the relatively rapid selection toward, and limited deviation from, this attractor rule out most hypothesized drivers of size increase. These three independent body size increases and a shared aquatic optimum size are consistent with control by differences in the scaling of energetic intake and cost functions with body size between the terrestrial and aquatic realms.

Rhinovirus is the major cause of the common cold. Although rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity, the mechanism by which rhinovirus exploits the cooler temperature is not known. Here, we show that rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity due, in part, to a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral strategies for the common cold.

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a major cause of infections in humans and animals. It is an opportunistic pathogen that can cause severe diseases in immunocompromised individuals, such as cystic fibrosis patients. The ability to sense the environment and adapt to changing conditions is critical for the survival of this pathogen. Here we show that P. aeruginosa uses the mechanical activity of its pili to sense surfaces and to regulate its virulence. This is an important discovery because it provides a mechanism for the pathogen to sense the environment on short timescales, which is critical for its survival.

This study provides a comprehensive analysis of the global occurrence of pesticides in surface water. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

This study provides evidence of the circulation of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living white-tailed deer in the United States. This finding has important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to obtain enhanced understanding of the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2.

The proliferation of large dams in the developing world is a major concern for the environment, the economy, and the social well-being of the people living in the areas where they are built. This paper examines the history of the development of hydropower and the reasons for the proliferation of large dams in the developing world. It also examines the problems that are being caused by these dams and the need to incorporate climate change into the considerations of whether to build a dam. Finally, it proposes innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the most common cause of death in the elderly. The cause of AD is unknown, but it is thought to be due to a combination of genetic and environmental factors. The most common pathological feature of AD is the presence of amyloid plaques and neurofibrillary tangles, which are thought to be the result of the accumulation of the proteins amyloid-β (Aβ) and tau, respectively. In this study, we show that Aβ is also a major contributor to the early immune response in the brain, and that it is the cause of the activation of microglia, the brain’s immune cells. This finding has implications for the development of new therapies for AD.

The domestication of the chicken (Gallus gallus) is one of the most important events in the history of agriculture. However, the earliest evidence for the economic use of chickens is still unknown. Here we present the results of a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens for economic purposes was widespread in the Southern Levant as early as the fourth century B.C.E. We further demonstrate that the adoption of chickens in European husbandry was preceded by at least a century by the finds in the Southern Levant. Our results suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process, and it is not known how many distinct intermediates are involved. This work shows that a large protein folds through distinct intermediates in two steps. The results suggest that the folding of a protein is a multistep process, and that the intermediates are important for folding.

In bacteria, the accumulation of dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) in response to stress is thought to be a mechanism for triggering rapid degradation of the transcripts that contain them. However, the predominant Np4 decapping enzyme in proteobacteria, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable Np4-capped RNAs to accumulate to high levels. Here, we show that, in such cells, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is not known to decape Np4-capped RNAs, is the predominant enzyme responsible for the deprotection of those transcripts. We also show that, in contrast to its known substrate specificity, RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to recognize other 5′ termini, resulting in a one-nucleotide shift in substrate specificity. These findings have implications for the ability of bacteria to rapidly adapt to stress. (Read more)

Sepsis is a major cause of mortality and morbidity, and the development of new therapeutic strategies is needed. We have shown that arginine, a key amino acid in the urea cycle, is essential for the maintenance of T cell function and proliferation during sepsis. This study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis.

The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass contains more consumers than producers. Finally, we highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a quantitative view of the biomass composition of the biosphere and can be used to understand the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. This article is protected by copyright. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in which a dynamical system, when perturbed, returns to a state of constant activity. SOC is observed in a variety of systems, including earthquakes, sandpiles, and neural networks. In this paper, we show that a sandpile model, the archetypal model of SOC, has a continuous scaling limit in the space of continuous functions. This is a first step toward understanding the nature of continuous models of SOC. We also discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, spintronics, and quantum technologies. However, it is not a perfect material, and it has some limitations. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely vanished, by applying strain. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work also provides a general framework for the study of the relationship between strain and electronic and phonon properties in solids. The male–female reproductive axis is a critical system for understanding the evolution of sex. In this study, we provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the Drosophila sperm proteome. We show that the proteome of the sperm changes substantially after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that the proteome of the female reproductive tract changes substantially after being transferred to the male reproductive tract. These findings provide a comprehensive characterization of the posttesticular life history of the sperm proteome and demonstrate that the proteome of the female reproductive tract changes substantially after being transferred to the male reproductive tract. Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that is critical for the clotting system. It is also important for the binding of platelets to the vascular wall. In some people, mutations in VWF cause bleeding disorders. We have shown that the A1 domain of VWF is important for binding to platelets. We have now shown that the A1 domain can be switched between two states by force. This provides a mechanism for the activation of VWF binding to platelets.

The human microbiome is a vast ecosystem of microorganisms that is now known to be associated with a wide range of health outcomes. However, the human virome, the set of viruses that live in and on humans, is poorly understood. Here, we present a comprehensive database of viruses from human samples, which can be used to study the human virome in the future. We find that viruses are strongly associated with a wide range of diseases, and that the virome is likely to be an important contributor to human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to observe simultaneously aerosol and cloud properties. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. The results of this study will help to improve the representation of ACI in climate models. This will help to improve the prediction of climate change. This technique is expected to be a significant contribution to the ACI research and climate science.

The temperature of Earth’s surface has a profound influence on the evolution of life. The temperature history of the surface is inferred to be linked to the temperature history of the deep interior, which in turn is linked to the evolution of the planet. This study provides a new method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past, and thus the evolution of the planet.

Ion channels are the main ion-conductive proteins in cells and are responsible for the flow of ions across the membrane. Ion channels are also the main targets of drugs and are involved in many diseases. Ion channels are normally open and close by opening and closing their pore gates. We found that the K+ channel BK has a unique property of closed state-dependent C-type inactivation. This finding provides a new perspective on the regulation of ion channels and may help us to understand the function of ion channels in health and disease.

Malaria is one of the most devastating diseases in the world, with 209 million cases and 555,000 deaths in 2015. The parasite, Plasmodium, uses a variety of mechanisms to invade the red blood cell (RBC) and initiate disease. Here, we show that the parasite uses a single protein, erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175), to alter the physical properties of the RBC membrane, reducing the energy barrier to invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the invasion process, suggesting that the parasite and host cell are working together to facilitate invasion. This work has implications for the development of new antimalarial strategies. (Read more)

Diamond is a unique material with a wide bandgap, high hardness, and high thermal and electrical conductivity. It is a promising material for optoelectronics, spintronics, and quantum technologies. However, it is not a perfect material, and it has some limitations. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, and its bandgap can be completely vanished, by applying strain. This work offers opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. This work also provides a general framework for exploring the properties of other materials. This work is expected to be useful for the development of new materials and applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease in humans and animals. In the temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While the impact of humidity on viral transmission is well established, the impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in mice lacking the effector caspase 1/11, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and may help to develop strategies to mitigate the impact of seasonal influenza outbreaks. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of the sentence as a whole from the bottom up, one word at a time. Here, we show that the brain is actually doing this all the time, and that it does it in the same way for every word in a sentence. This is a fundamental property of the language system, and it is consistent with the idea that the brain is building a tree of phrases.

Axin is a key component of the Wnt signaling pathway, which is involved in development and homeostasis. In this study, we show that the two forms of Axin in vertebrates are not only similar at the protein level but also in their regulation. We show that the two forms of Axin are regulated in a tissue-specific manner, which may be important for the proper functioning of the Wnt pathway.

Obesity is a major health problem in the United States and worldwide. It is associated with a number of chronic diseases, including type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular disease, and certain types of cancer. The causes of obesity are complex and include genetic and environmental factors. However, it is clear that the brain plays a critical role in the development of obesity. Here we describe a brain circuit that may contribute to the development of obesity and overeating.

Nitrogen is the most essential nutrient for plant growth and productivity, but its availability is limited in many agricultural systems. Thus, the development of strategies to increase nitrogen availability is of great importance. Here, we demonstrate the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the nitrogenase, the enzyme that converts atmospheric nitrogen into a form plants can use, is turned on only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This work also provides a proof of concept for the use of rhizopine as a synthetic signaling molecule.

We study the effects of a community-based monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals are surrounded by sound, and hearing is a fundamental sense of many animals. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is outsourced to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web.

We show that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The emergence of variants of concern has raised concerns about the efficacy of vaccines against COVID-19. Here we report the design of a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the spike protein of SARS-CoV-2 that is highly manufacturable, binds to ACE2 with high affinity, and elicits antibodies with enhanced immunogenicity. This engineered RBD can be presented on a virus-like particle, which reduces weight loss in hamsters upon viral challenge. These results suggest that the engineered RBD may be a useful tool for vaccine development against variants of concern. This engineered RBD may also be useful for the development of vaccines against other coronaviruses.

Neuroblastoma is the most common tumor of neural crest-derived tissues in children. In the present study, we provide evidence for the involvement of a family of zebrafish ALK-related kinases in the development of neural crest-derived tissues.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and the pathogen that causes it has been responsible for multiple outbreaks throughout the course of human civilization. This study provides a comprehensive view of the evolution of plague during the early stages of its development, when it was still adapting to its new host, the flea. We show that the emergence of plague from its progenitor lineage was a long and complex process, and that the disease underwent a series of evolutionary steps before it became adapted to its new host. We also show that the emergence of plague was a global event, and that the disease spread across Eurasia and into Europe during the Bronze Age. These findings provide important insights into the origins of plague and its relationship with its host, the flea. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in the 2016 and 2020 presidential elections. We found that men’s and women’s endorsement of HM predicted support for Donald Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. These findings have implications for understanding the political climate in the United States and beyond.

Soil organic carbon (SOC) is a key component of soil health and a critical resource for the global food supply. In the United States, the conversion of grassland to cropland has led to a massive release of SOC to the atmosphere. This study shows that soil health management practices can mitigate this trend and that well-managed grasslands can store more SOC than annual cropping systems. These results highlight the potential of grasslands to contribute to climate-smart agriculture and the importance of maintaining and restoring grasslands for the long-term storage of SOC.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of zoonotic viruses to humans. We have developed a framework to identify the key factors that contribute to the risk of spillover and spread of viruses from animals to humans. We have also created a web tool that allows users to explore the risk of spillover of viruses from animals to humans. This tool can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is an important trait that attracts pollinators, but the mechanisms that underlie the production of nectar pigments are poorly understood. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the distantly related and hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. This work demonstrates that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation, and that the color of nectar is a convergently evolved trait.

The history of Europe is marked by a complex interplay of demographic processes, including waves of immigration from outside the continent. However, the genetic history of the period between the migrations of the Huns and the Roman conversion to Christianity is largely unknown. Here we present the genome of 11 individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. The analysis of the collective genetic ancestry of these individuals indicates that women had a much more complex demographic history than men, and that the genetic heterogeneity of the population may have contributed to the shaping of the modern European genetic landscape. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) is a zoonotic pathogen that causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. This study is a proof of concept for the use of metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) in the surveillance of undifferentiated febrile illness in a resource-scarce setting. We show that mNGS can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens, including chikungunya virus, which was detected in the early stages of a national outbreak. This study also highlights the importance of coordinated and ongoing pathogen surveillance to better understand the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and to deploy rapid public health response. The human genome is replicated in the nucleus of the cell. This process is essential for the survival of the cell and the organism. The process is complex and requires the cooperation of many proteins. One of the proteins that is involved in the replication of the genome is the sliding clamp, proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA). PCNA is a protein that is involved in the replication of the genome and the repair of DNA damage. In this study, we show that the sliding clamp, PCNA, is involved in the replication of the genome.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, it has been possible to evolve ribozymes that can replicate RNA, but it has been difficult to evolve ribozymes that can replicate RNA in the presence of proteins. Here, we report the successful evolution of a ribozyme that can replicate RNA in the presence of proteins. This work represents a major step toward the creation of a functional RNA world in the laboratory. It also provides a model for the evolution of ribozyme-based genetic systems. Finally, it may provide a platform for the development of new technologies for the synthesis of RNA and the amplification of nucleic acids.

This paper introduces a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearance of five US cities with economic and demographic data and find three factors that predict neighborhood improvement. First, neighborhoods that are densely populated by college-educated adults are more likely to experience physical improvements—an observation that is compatible with the economic literature linking human capital and local success. Second, neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements—an observation that is consistent with “tipping” theories of urban change. Third, neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods—an observation that is consistent with the “invasion” theories of urban sociology. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our work also provides a method for measuring the physical appearance of neighborhoods that can be used to monitor the physical health of cities over time. This method can be used to study the physical dynamics of cities and to inform urban planning and policy.

COVID-19 is a severe disease with high mortality. The treatment is mainly supportive. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the interleukin 6 pathways, is effective in the treatment of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is expected that this study will provide a reference for the treatment of COVID-19 in the future.

Copper is an essential micronutrient, but also a toxic metal that can cause oxidative damage. The ability of fungi to sequester copper in the form of metal-binding metabolites is a relatively new discovery, and the mechanisms by which fungi regulate copper homeostasis are not well understood. Here we demonstrate that the xan biosynthetic gene cluster in Aspergillus fumigatus is involved in the binding of copper, and that the secreted metabolites have antimicrobial properties. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a role for eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. This discovery has implications for the development of antifungal and antibacterial therapeutics. (Read more)

The presence of tridymite in a sedimentary rock from Gale crater, Mars, is significant because it is a high-temperature (>870 °C) polymorph of silica that is commonly associated with silicic volcanism. The presence of such a mineral in a sedimentary rock from Mars is also significant because it suggests that silicic volcanism occurred on the planet in the past.

Frost is one of the most common abiotic stressors that affect plants and animals in the Northern Hemisphere. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is changing, and that this change is likely to increase the risk of frost damage to plants. We also show that the resistance strategies of plants are likely to be the main driver of this change.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not well understood. Here, we show that the development of Th17 cells is contingent on the expression of both Stat4 and T-bet, but not the IL-12 or IL-17 receptors. Moreover, we show that Th17 cells can provide “help” for the development of classic Th1 cells. These results indicate that Th17 cells are potent mediators of colitis pathogenesis by dual mechanisms: by directly transitioning to Th1-like cells and by supporting the development of classic Th1 cells. These findings have implications for the development of therapeutic strategies for inflammatory bowel disease. (PsycINFO Database Record

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by degeneration of motor neurons, which are the key drivers of paralysis. In this study, we report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. Our method is easy to perform and can be used to study the disease in the context of the patient’s own cells. This will help us to understand the disease and develop more effective treatments.

This study provides a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen, Anaplasma phagocytophilum, exploits the host arthropod vector to enhance colonization. This work also provides a framework for the development of new strategies to prevent the transmission of infectious diseases.

Birds are one of the most successful groups of animals on Earth, and the study of their evolution is a key component of understanding the origin of modern biodiversity. This study describes a new basal member of the group of birds with a short tail, and provides insights into the evolution of the avian tail and the origin of the modern avian bauplan.

We show that the tropical tropopause layer plays an important role in the climate system. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause.

Vertebrates have a variety of colors, from red to blue, and many of them have the ability to change color. This ability is important for the survival of the animals, as it allows them to adapt to their environment. In this study, we show that the ability to change color has evolved multiple times during the evolution of vertebrates.

Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide, and the leading cause of cancer death. Breast cancer stem cells (BCSCs) are responsible for the initiation and maintenance of metastasis. In this study, we show that hypoxia induces expression of AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which in turn increases the expression of NANOG, a gene that encodes a pluripotency factor. NANOG expression is regulated by HIF-1α and HIF-2α, and is dependent on ALKBH5. NANOG expression is required for the maintenance of BCSCs, and ALKBH5 expression is required for the induction of BCSCs by hypoxia. Thus, our findings suggest that ALKBH5 may be a potential target for the treatment of breast cancer. (Read more)

The Bible is one of the most important books in the world. It is also one of the most fragile. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century, and the source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. This paper reports the results of a study of 465 parchment samples, including 72 pocket Bibles, to determine the origin of the animal skins used to make them. The results suggest that the skins of maturing animals of several species were used to make the parchment, rather than the use of abortive or newborn animals.

The end-Permian mass extinction was the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is a matter of debate, but the timing of the event is well established. Here we provide a precise age model for the extinction and recovery, which will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic disease that affects the gastrointestinal tract. Although the exact cause of IBD is unknown, it is believed to be associated with the immune system. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) plays an important role in the regulation of intestinal inflammation. We also found that RORα is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. Our results suggest that RORα could be a potential target for the treatment of IBD.

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for the immune system of the host and for the development of vaccines and antibodies. We have determined the structure of the spike glycoprotein in complex with the receptor ACE2 at 3.0 Å resolution. This structure provides a basis for understanding the mechanism of binding and fusion, and the impact of the D614G mutation.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that, in 2020, the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth for the total US population and for Black and Latino Americans by more than 1 y, and life expectancy at age 65 y by more than 0.8 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y, thereby eliminating progress made in reducing this differential since 2006. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites (a phenomenon known as the Latino or Hispanic paradox), would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y.

The chemical behavior of atoms is one of the most important aspects of chemistry. It is also one of the most difficult to understand. This work shows that the chemical behavior of atoms can be described in terms of two simple properties: electronegativity and chemical hardness. These properties can be calculated as a function of pressure, and they can be used to predict and explain the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure. This work provides a new way to understand the chemical behavior of atoms, and it can be used to predict and explain the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase the frequency and intensity of fires, which can have important consequences for the global carbon cycle. However, the effects of climate change on fire activity are uncertain, and the role of human ignitions is not well understood. We show that changes in human demography can reduce fire activity, which in turn can reduce warming. This effect is most pronounced under lower emissions scenarios, and it is likely to be important in mitigating future warming. Our results highlight the importance of human ignitions in modulating fire regimes, and they suggest that climate change may be less important in driving fire activity than previously thought.

This study shows that the delivery of a single glycan to a symbiotic organism is sufficient to regulate the activities of the symbionts and the health of the host. This glycan is produced by the host, and its delivery to the symbiont is triggered by the host’s own physiology. This glycan is catabolized by the symbiont, which uses the resulting metabolites to maintain a healthy symbiosis. This glycan is also required for the host’s own physiology, which is important for the health of the symbiont. This study provides a new perspective on the symbiosis between the squid Euprymna scolopes and its bioluminescent symbiont, Vibrio fischeri, and it suggests that the delivery of glycans to symbionts may be a general mechanism for the regulation of symbiosis. This mechanism may be important for the health of the host and the symbiont, and it may also be important for the health of the symbiosis.

Text data are ubiquitous, and the need to identify latent patterns in them is growing. We introduce a method to identify topics in a corpus and represent documents as topic sequences. This method is based on advances in theoretical machine learning, which we combine with a sparse representation of word embeddings. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe.

Asteroids are a keystone species in the marine ecosystem, and their population decline is a major concern for the functioning of marine food webs. We provide evidence that a densovirus is responsible for the mass mortality of asteroids on the Pacific Coast of North America. This is the first report of a densovirus associated with a disease outbreak in asteroids. The discovery of this virus has important implications for the conservation of this ecologically and economically important group of animals.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia, and the prognosis of patients with AML is poor. The identification of AML stem cells is important for the development of more efficient therapies. Here, we show that an antibody targeting the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is able to target AML stem cells and that this antibody is able to block IL-1 signaling. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This approach may be useful for the treatment of other diseases in which IL-1 signaling is important. Furthermore, the development of this antibody may be useful for the treatment of other diseases in which IL1RAP is important.

Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity. However, the settlement history of Madagascar is still debated. Here, we provide a high-resolution view of the genomic diversity of the Malagasy population, which is a unique opportunity to study the settlement history of Madagascar. We find that Madagascar is a unique island in terms of its biodiversity and its cultural diversity.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity.
